gauzy: The surface of a gauzy object is covered in thin, translucent fabric.

cracked: Cracked material is usually dry and has a rough surface.

stratified: There is no definitive answer to this question because it can depend on the specific rock being observed.

scaly: A scaly material usually has a rough, dry texture with small scales that can be flaked or peeled off.

swirly: A "swirly" texture looks like a series of curves and swirls.

perforated: A "perforated" surface has small holes all over it.

pleated: A pleated surface is one that has been formed by folding or pressing fabric so that it forms a series of parallel folds.

flecked: A flecked thing looks like it has tiny pieces of another substance sprinkled on top of it.

polka-dotted: A polka-dotted thing looks like a thing with small, round spots on it.

chequered: A chequered thing is usually black and white, or some other combination of two colors.

blotchy: A blotchy thing looks like a thing that has Blotches on it.

stained: A "stained" texture is a texture that has been purposely discolored or faded in order to create a certain look.

crystalline: A crystalline object is typically transparent or translucent.

porous: A porous material has tiny holes throughout it.

banded: Banded patterns typically have stripes of different colors or shades going horizontally across the fabric.

lacelike: A lacelike surface has a delicate, intricate, and open structure.

sprinkled: A "sprinkled" object looks like it has been covered with a small amount of a substance, typically in a random or irregular pattern.

bubbly: A bubbly material is one that has a lot of small holes orWh bubbles in it.

lined: A lined pattern is usually a series of parallel lines.

veined: A veined surface is a surface with a pattern of lines or streaks that resemble veins.

bumpy: "Bumpy" material typically has a textured surface with small bumps or ridges.

paisley: A paisley texture often looks like a teardrop-shaped decorative element with a curved stem.

potholed: A "potholed" object may have small, round depressions on its surface that resemble the holes that form in a road when water seeps in and the pavement deteriorates.

spiralled: A "spiralled" object is any object that has a spiral shape.

grooved: Grooved material has parallel lines cut into it, usually for the purpose of decoration or to create a rougher surface.

dotted: A surface that is dotted looks like it has a lot of small bumps or pits.

interlaced: A "interlaced" object is an object that has a pattern of crossing lines.

crosshatched: Crosshatched material typically has a pattern of parallel lines that intersect at right angles.

wrinkled: Wrinkled material is material that has been creased, folded, or twisted so that it is no longer smooth.

smeared: "Smeared" material looks like a blur or a smear.

striped: A "striped" object is an object that has stripes on it.

braided: A braided material is a type of fabric that has been woven together in a narrowd, interlacing pattern.

freckled: A freckled texture looks like a small, dark spot on the surface of something.

cobwebbed: Cobwebbed surfaces are often dusty and have a lot of spiders webs on them.

honeycombed: A honeycomb is a mass of hexagonal wax cells built by bees in their nests to contain their larvae and stores of honey.
woven: The word "woven" is used to describe a type of fabric that is created by interlacing two sets of threads at right angles.

matted: The term "matted" typically refers to a material that is tangled, knotted, or otherwise stuck together in a clump.

zigzagged: A zigzag is a series of sharp turns in alternating directions.

marbled: A marbled thing has a lot of different colors mixed together.

studded: A studded pattern can be achieved by dotting beads or rhinestones around an item in a irregular or random pattern.

grid: A grid pattern is a series of vertical and horizontal lines that intersect to form a series of squares or rectangles.
